ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about different music terminology and patterns in music over history. This is definitely a music history course more than it is a music appreciation course.

I learned about the many themes that pervade in the lyrics throughout the history of love songs. I also learned about the culture of love (i.e. how love was portrayed between people, in which contexts or settings is a scene involving love typically set in in literary works or music, famous literary pieces about love, the troubadours, etc), and how that culture surrounding love has changed from the medieval era to modern times. I also learned about the specific choices that composers make when writing up the music for their song to achieve their intended tone for the song!

How to actively listen to songs of all types by identifying basic musical structures and concepts, connecting them to larger musical choices in narration and theme. Addressing the why behind every major musical choice, and connecting songs to cultures and historical movements.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Z was so much fun to have in class, but I wish her lectures about music history were more cohesive and put together. She was a bit scattered in her lecturing, and some slides or supplementary material to her lectures would be helpful.

Strengths: Prof Z does a great job at teaching the musical and cultural history behind love songs and she's an amazing professor. The small class size also allows for the students to get to know each other closely (my class actually ended up being fairly connected with each other outside of class!), and allow for engaging discussions. You also get to listen to music as homework and some of the songs slap. Also you don't need to know any music knowledge to do well in the course!! (I came in knowing nothing about sheet music or musical terms and Prof Z taught us what we needed to know to do the assignments and be able to engage in class).
Weaknesses: the amount of songs we had to listen to per class increased substantially in the later half of the semester once we moved to the American parlor song stage; I personally didn't mind the increase in workload, but I'm thinking that maybe other students did.

Strengths: provides a strong introduction to a series of major musical movements in Western artistic history. There were so many spaces for creative interpretation and discussion. Professor Zayaruznaya and our TA Emily led insightful conversations, debates and lectures combined with active listening. A series of fascinating readings, which were indispensable to the class. For improvements, perhaps Prof Z could have asked us to post a short comment and question we had about each set of readings into a Canvas blog prior to class. Sometimes I digested our readings a bit passively, and this feature may have helped. Also, it could further prime the discussion and get us thinking critically about the texts before we enter class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the use of the chat to put down musical terms that we should know, like obbligato instruments and basso continuo.

I appreciated how Prof. Z and Emily often shared their screen to provide visuals of relevant musical scores or slides. I also found it helpful when they played relevant portions of songs by sharing audio.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a fun class because I loved my classmates and the professor, but the actual content did get pretty boring at times. The bulk of the music we learn about is French or German, and that kind of took the enjoyment out of listening to the music because we had to keep track of the translation. Fun class, but content was boring

YESS! This class is amazing, you learn so much about the history and culture of love songs in interesting ways you never thought about before. The class has also taught me to listen more closely to the music and lyrics behind a song rather than just letting them wash over me. It was also my favorite class this semester because the small seminar discussion format allowed me to engage with the material and get to know my fellow classmates and the professor. The workload isn't bad and the professor is great. You don't need to have any background in music to enjoy the class!

Sure. It is a great introduction to the college seminar format and dives into a topic always ripe for critique, debate, and discussionalthough many of our classes leaned more heavily on the lecture style. Also provides a great overview of several musical periods! This courses workload is very manageable. If you love music, wish to expand your horizons in the field of music (not theory--we dont really cover that here), and would like a less demanding course to balance out other more taxing ones, go for it! Prof Z is a wonderful professor and is great at leading discussions and lectures.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
